newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft, Intel unveil Internet video software.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft, Intel unveil Internet video software.

text.p: Microsoft Corp and Intel Corp Monday unveiled seperate, yet compatible software for real-time video communications over the Internet.

Microsoft's NetMeeting version 2.0 beta 2 and Intel's Internet Video Phone beta 1.0 will enable computer users to place video calls over the Internet, they said. Both programs comply with industry standards for video conferencing.
They are available for free at the corrosponding firms' Internet World Wide Web site.

Intel's Internet Video Phone adds a visual dimension to Internet activities, like linking video phone calls to on-line chats, or observing opponents as they compete on-line in games. Microsoft NetMeeting is a real-time communications client application for consumer and business communications and provides an open, standards-based platform for third-party companies to build and integrate solutions.
Intel and Microsoft said they hope to make personal computer-based video, voice and data communications over the Internet as commonplace as a simple telephone call.
"We have been working closely with Intel and the industry to remove interoperability as a barrier to market growth," Microsoft executive John Ludwig said in a statement.
